Award.AwardTitle: NSF Postdoctoral Fellowship in Biology FY 2014
Award.AbstractNarration:
NSF Postdoctoral Fellowships in Biology combine research and training components to prepare young scientists for careers in biology and require a plan to broaden participation of groups under-represented in science and engineering. The fellowships advance NSF efforts to diversify the STEM workforce now and in the future. This fellowship to C. Marisa Tellez supports research and training in predicting the health status of aquatic ecosystems by studying crocodilian top predators and their parasites. The host institution is the University of California, Santa Barbara under the sponsorship of Dr. Armand Kuris. The lack of data on community diversity of crocodilian habitats hinders the ability of conservation managers to properly assess how anthropogenic disturbances affect wildlife. Training objectives include techniques in community ecology, biochemistry, and parasitology in order to assay biological indicators.

The research examines the significance of parasites as biodiversity and health indicators of crocodilian habitats. First, the study determines if parasite species richness correlates with biodiversity. Second, heavy metal analyses of hosts and parasites, representing three different trophic levels, are being used to evaluate human impact. Analyzing pollutant levels in both hosts and parasites is a novel approach to assess anthropogenic impact. This may provide a more advantageous indicator of ecosystem functioning, and of environmental quality, than is presently available. Overall, the proposed analyses foster novel theories and ideals about the function of community interactions, energy flow and food web relationships in tropical systems.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The lack of data on community diversity of crocodilian habitats hinders the ability of conservation managers to properly assess how human disturbances and natural disasters affect wildlife, and in turn, how this may ultimately affect the communities that depend on these environments for their livelihood (i.e., food, shelter, medicine and tourism). Given the ancient lineage and status of crocodilians as keystone predators, as well as parasites’ dependency on host and environment, my project examined the use of crocodilians and their parasites as biological indicators of the local biodiversity and health of crocodilian habitats through a cross-disciplinary approach that includes community ecology, parasitology, eco-toxicology, and translational ecology (= utilizing scientific data to implement management and conservation action plans). 

 

My project has focused on three crocodilian habitats in Belize:  Ambergris Caye, Caye Caulker, and more specifically Placencia Lagoon in southern Belize.  The project included conducting bird surveys, aquatic surveys, and crocodile surveys in addition to dissecting snails and fish for their parasites, as well as collecting poop from the American crocodile (Crocodylus acutus) and Morelet’s crocodile (Crocodylus moreletii) or conducting stomach flushing to obtain nematode parasites. Abiotic measurments (salinity, pH, and dissolved oxygen) were recorded to examine if these variables affected parasite prevalence, intensity or abundance.  Original data was collected between the dry and wet seasons of Belize, but the last year data was collected every month in Placencia Lagoon as wet and dry seasons have become blurred over the years. 

 

So what did I find?  The data did show a distinct contrast of parasite prevalence and diversity between pristine vs. non-pristine crocodilian habitats; the more pristine habitats had a higher diversity of parasite prevalence, including a higher prevalence of trematode parasites that use multiple hosts for their life cycle.  Part of the trematode life cycle includes a free-living stage and it is very sensitive to fluctuations or pollution in its surrounding aquatic habitat, thus low trematode prevalence provides a red flag that something is unstable or negatively affecting the ecosystem.  Additionally, the health and parasitism of crocodiles seemed to reflect the state of the environment, particularly the external parasite known as Paratrichosoma.  This parasites leaves a zig-zag trail on the ventral side of crocs, and it was noticed in hypersaline, low oxygenated, or highly polluted environments crocs did not have this parasite.  More research will be pursued to understand how this croc parasite interacts more with its archaic host and the aquatic environment.

 

In the Placencia Lagoon, my research provided cryptic details of an aquatic environment that was losing its biodiversity; no one had noticed the issues as more traditional methods (water testing and basic biodiversity surveys 1/year) were not illustrating the red flags.  The Placencia Lagoon is currently being considered as a Wildlife Sancutary in Belize, and the data my research provided (the sudden decrease in parasitism in certain areas of the lagoon followed by a noticeable drop of bird diversity as well as diseased birds, the decrease of snails) supplemented information necessary to rapidly incorporate the nation’s Department of the Environment and local NGO’s to further investigate what is harming the Placencia Lagoon.  As a result, I’ve been asked to continue my research (which will now turn into a 20 year project minimum), as well as one of the key consultants in the establishment of the Placencia Lagoon as a Wildlife Sanctuary.

 

Besides the pure research, I realize that consistent involvement, enthusiasm and guidance are essential for the preservation of the threatened ecosystems in Latin America, as well as for future scientific projects in the region.  While conducting research in Belize, I involved local wildlife biologists, high school and college students, as well as other community members to participate in my project, turning my project into a Citizen Science project. Particularly for students, this opportunity provided them research experience that they may not have obtained otherwise, ultimately enabling native students to enhance science and promote sustainability of the local biodiversity. Additionally, the project developed proved to be cost-effective and applicable to other environments in Belize, which could further the conservation management here with the few resources available.
